results.content:
I've gone through this course twice.  It does cover the basics without giving too much information (I do like brevity in some situations).  Icaro is a real person, he makes mistakes (spelling, bugs etc) but goes back and fixes them.  I like that, it shows it's real and not some heavily edited course.  However there are problems, the course is not complete, and the last few videos (I blame Covid) are a bit messed up (a 12 min video is actually 2 videos joined together).  

Could be better and I'll visit again once the course is complete.  Needs a polish though and for the videos to all be reviewed.

results.content: Wonderful delivery, voice is clear and content knowledge beyond!
results.content_html: Wonderful delivery, voice is clear and content knowledge beyond!

results.content:
hi Icaro, you've actual gone above and beyond what you agreed to cover in the overview? I'd consider removing the very last section where you add the auth until the entire auth section is complete as it gives the impression that it's incomplete which is incorrect. 

With that said, I can honestly say I thought this course was excellent! I really enjoyed the bite sized 3/4/5 minute lessons which were invaluable when I was trying to sneak in a few during lunch or on a break. Your familiarity with the Amplify dashboard, Visual Studio code (snippets) are invaluable. Also your ability to encounter and fix issues on the fly really made me as a student feel confident that I was learning from a real pro. Congratulations on a great course and thanks for taking the time to put it together. I will recommend it to any colleagues looking for an intro to Amplify.

Thanks,
Mark.

results.content: The course is about building a whole App with AWS Amplify and React, and does just that. Learning by doing. You should be able to install the different parts yourself, and at least have an account on AWS and Github, basic knowledge of React and Graphql is an advantage. This course uses functions and hooks and the backend from AWS is up to date and easy to follow. The instructor is very helpful and answers all the questions in a short time. There are some minor flaws and some lessons to be added as the course is brandnew.
results.content_html: The course is about building a whole App with AWS Amplify and React, and does just that. Learning by doing. You should be able to install the different parts yourself, and at least have an account on AWS and Github, basic knowledge of React and Graphql is an advantage. This course uses functions and hooks and the backend from AWS is up to date and easy to follow. The instructor is very helpful and answers all the questions in a short time. There are some minor flaws and some lessons to be added as the course is brandnew.

results.content: I highly recommend this course to any wanting to ramp up the skill set. GraphQL is a very smart approach to pooling data from many different datasources. AWS Amplify and AppSync help make the job of creating GraphQL compliant client side applications much easier.  Icaro does a excellent job of guiding you step by step through the process.
results.content_html: I highly recommend this course to any wanting to ramp up the skill set. GraphQL is a very smart approach to pooling data from many different datasources. AWS Amplify and AppSync help make the job of creating GraphQL compliant client side applications much easier. Icaro does a excellent job of guiding you step by step through the process.

results.content: The course is good but in its current state it is not finished. If it did conclude and the rest of the material was as good I would definitely rate this a 4 minimum.

response.content: Hi Jason, thank you so much for taking the time to post this excellent review. I want to let you know that the course is not incomplete; per se, the course's multipage part is (at the moment) because it is an extended version (a bonus) of the course. I have been adding it because of student's requests, and I separate some time every month to update or create new content for all the courses. However, the course's main part covers all the Amplify details deeper than any course I have to see on the internet. We cover everything from auth, storage, lambda, graphql, CI/CD deployment, and even react implementation details such as custom hooks and much more. Anyway, new content for this course is coming up this week. What should close the multipage part of this course and for future sessions, I'll try to be much clear on where the course ends and where the new bonus content started so students can be sure of what is happening. (and hopefully, after that, we can see few more starts on your review :) Once again, thank you and keep in touch

I have been adding it because of student's requests, and I separate some time every month to update or create new content for all the courses. However, the course's main part covers all the Amplify details deeper than any course I have to see on the internet. We cover everything from auth, storage, lambda, graphql, CI/CD deployment, and even react implementation details such as custom hooks and much more. (and hopefully, after that, we can see few more starts on your review :) Once again, thank you and keep in touch

results.content_html: The course is good but in its current state it is not finished. If it did conclude and the rest of the material was as good I would definitely rate this a 4 minimum.

results.content:
Icaro is a good teacher but course is hard to follow at times. Code gets refactored all of the sudden and I needed to waste time going back and forth his github to check what's it meant to be. Links and resources should also be easier to find. 

Also, there's no commits related to lectures so if you get lost... good luck. 

I really wish I could leave a better rating. The course has a potential and I do enjoy his teaching style. That said , currently it just seems to be a beta version ( I hope ).

response.content: Hey Tomasz, thank you for your feedback. I must say that I really fail to commit the code in each class. Sometimes when you in a flow is hard to remember to stop and commit the code (I'm doing better concerning this now). I like the constantly refactored the code because it is how I program, and I also want to pass this information to you (as I believe it is vital). Otherwise, some students think, "How did you know you would need this or that?" I want to show that there is no magic. However, if you get lost, I'm always around to answer any questions. I normally answer the questions in few hours, even on weekends (unless I'm sleeping, of course). I'm adding more content to this course and also makes some classes more clear, if you have any recommendation on with classes were problematic for your, please let me know I would love to hear from you.

results.content: Excellent course, Icaro explains everything step by step without waist time. The course is precise to the point and he makes sure that even the less knowledgeable students can follow the course in a way that does not bode the more knowledgeable ones. 10 Starts!

results.content:
- The instructor isn't replying to my QA questions at all.
- He isn't explaining what is going on (mostly just describing what he is doing and nothing about WHY)
-He may be experienced developer but he ISN'T an experienced instructor. After the courses you don't feel like you expanded your knowledge, more like having the feel of progressing an app without knowing much about it.
-His example app (especially the schema) is very confusing for a beginner, he couldn't just have a list of cars,students,clothes...etc?? Had to be List of lists? Its kinda confusing all the time of what exactly you are doing.
-I haven't finished the course, i'm 1/4 way in and desperate. 
The combination of technologies and core content is very interesting but also other than what i mentioned above, on section 11:chapter 25 suddenly more code appears! (like a video is missing) And the content continues like the explanation about this part exists in previous videos (i'm talking about the "update list" case in use reducer). I have to manually try to find out how he implemented the code behind the scenes to continue the course now!

I am really exciting into learning more about Amplify,AppSync,React amazon AWS in general BUT i'm sick of this course. 

I want officially to ask for a refund even the 30 days passed cause the course is useless without QA and with missing parts inside that i can find a way to implement myself...(I'm talking about the one in Section 11 i mentioned above)

- The instructor isn't replying to my QA questions at all.
- He isn't explaining what is going on (mostly just describing what he is doing and nothing about WHY)
-He may be experienced developer but he ISN'T an experienced instructor. After the courses you don't feel like you expanded your knowledge, more like having the feel of progressing an app without knowing much about it.
-His example app (especially the schema) is very confusing for a beginner, he couldn't just have a list of cars,students,clothes...etc?? Had to be List of lists? Its kinda confusing all the time of what exactly you are doing.
-I haven't finished the course, i'm 1/4 way in and desperate.
The combination of technologies and core content is very interesting but also other than what i mentioned above, on section 11:chapter 25 suddenly more code appears! (like a video is missing) And the content continues like the explanation about this part exists in previous videos (i'm talking about the "update list" case in use reducer). I have to manually try to find out how he implemented the code behind the scenes to continue the course now!

I am really exciting into learning more about Amplify,AppSync,React amazon AWS in general BUT i'm sick of this course.

I want officially to ask for a refund even the 30 days passed cause the course is useless without QA and with missing parts inside that i can find a way to implement myself...(I'm talking about the one in Section 11 i mentioned above)
